item.title: MinuteCast by AccuWeather can be accessed on the Garmin vivoactive HR smartwatch
item.description:
AccuWeather, a leading provider of global weather information and digital media, announced today that its hyperlocal weather forecasting tool, AccuWeather MinuteCast, is now available on the new Garmin vivoactive HR smartwatch. MinuteCast was already available on other Garmin devices, such as the Forerunner and fēnix running and training watches. The Garmin vivoactive HR is a GPS smartwatch with wrist heart rate technology that allows users to track the intensity of their activities, monitor their progress, and keep tabs on their activity throughout the day...

item.title: YouGov is tracking the impact of the haze
item.description:
Southeast Asia faced significant haze this year, mainly due to regional forest fires. A YouGov survey reveals a high level of awareness about this issue within the region. Nearly 80% of Asian respondents are aware of the haze originating from Indonesian landscape fires. This awareness is lower in Hong Kong (48%) and Mainland China (44%). However, in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore, the three countries most affected, only 2% of respondents in each country reported being unaware of the haze...

item.title: Adapt your beauty routine to the changing weather conditions
item.description:
Mintel Beauty & Personal Care (BPC) has recognized a new global beauty trend: seasonality. This trend reflects how different weather conditions influence beauty routines. Source: Mintel website. According to Mintel BPC, product launches related to this trend significantly increased from 9.8% in 2011 to 11.1% in 2014. This is particularly noticeable in facial skincare, where seasonal product launches grew from a mere 0.5% in 2009 to 1.2% in 2014. Jane Henderson, Global President of Mintel’s Beauty and Personal Care Division, notes a growing consumer awareness of how environmental changes impact their skin and hair...

item.title: International SOS offers three tips for managing heatwaves
item.description:
As temperatures remain high in mid-2023, individuals may experience heat-related illness symptoms like rashes, cramps, dizziness, headaches, weakness, nausea/vomiting, or even collapse, according to Dr. Chan Yanjun, Medical Director (Singapore and Malaysia) at International SOS. Dr. Chan emphasizes that heat-related illnesses and fatalities are preventable with appropriate measures. Increased Risks Certain groups are more susceptible to heat-related issues like cramps, exhaustion, and stroke: individuals over 65, pregnant or nursing women, those with medical conditions or taking medications, people frequently outdoors, employees near heat sources or in poorly ventilated areas, and those working with hot objects, wearing heavy clothing/gear, or on long shifts...
